notes:
1. Average End Area Method

This is the most common method for calculating earthwork volumes between two cross-sections (stations).

$$ V = L \frac{A_1 + A_2}{2} $$
  • $V$: Volume between stations.
  • $A_1, A_2$: Cross-sectional areas at the two stations.
  • $L$: Distance between stations.

This method is exact only if the cross-sectional areas change linearly.

2. Prismoidal Formula

The Prismoidal Formula provides a more accurate volume calculation, especially when the ground profile is irregular or when there is a significant difference between the end areas.

$$ V = \frac{L}{6} (A_1 + 4A_m + A_2) $$
  • $A_m$: Cross-sectional area at the midpoint between the two stations.

3. Borrow Pit Method (Grid Method)

Used for site grading volume calculations where a grid of elevations is established. The volume of cut or fill within each grid cell is calculated by multiplying the cell area by the average depth of cut/fill at the corners.

solvedExamples.question: Using the Average End Area method, calculate the volume of fill between two stations 100 ft apart. The fill area at Station 1 is 200 sq ft, and the fill area at Station 2 is 300 sq ft.
solvedExamples.explanation: Volume = L * (A1 + A2) / 2 = 100 * (200 + 300) / 2 = 100 * 250 = 25,000 cubic feet. To convert to cubic yards, divide by 27: 25,000 / 27 = 925.9 cubic yards.

solvedExamples.question: The Prismoidal Formula is generally considered more accurate than the Average End Area method because:

options.text: It uses three cross-sectional areas instead of two.
It assumes linear variation between end areas.

solvedExamples.explanation: The Prismoidal Formula accounts for the curvature of the solid between the two end sections by including the area of the mid-section ($A_m$), providing a better approximation for solids that are not simple prisms.
